instruction:
Describe tumor progression across these 3 consecutive brain MRI slices (10-slice intervals). 
Segmentation colors indicate:
- RED: Non-Enhancing Tumor Core (NCR/NET) - necrotic tumor tissue
- GREEN: Peritumoral Edema (ED) - swelling around the tumor
- BLUE: Enhancing Tumor (ET) - actively growing tumor tissue
ground_truth: Across these 3 consecutive slices (10-slice intervals), the tumor shows: The lesion area is in the left parietal lobe region with a mix of heterogeneous high and low signals with patchy high signal areas. Edema is significant, mainly located in the left parietal lobe with intense and extensive signal, indicating considerable swelling of the surrounding tissue. Necrosis is a potentially necrotic area located in the right parietal lobe, manifesting as a mixed high signal region and exhibiting a patchy signal, concentrated at the center of the main lesion. Ventricular compression is minor deformation of some ventricles, suggesting a certain degree of compression is present.

ground_truth: The tumor progression through these 3 slices demonstrates: The lesion area is in the right frontal lobe of the brain with mixed signals of varying intensities and patchy high-signal areas, suggesting multiple lesions. Edema is significant, occupying a large portion of the right hemisphere with higher signal intensity, indicating swelling of the tissues around the lesion. Necrosis is potentially present in the deep regions of the right frontal lobe, showing markedly low signal intensity intermingled with regions of high signal lesions. Ventricular compression is observed with the right lateral ventricle notably compressed and deformed, while the left lateral ventricle also shows slight compression, suggesting the lesion has a significant impact on the ventricular system.

ground_truth: Examining this single slice, I observe: The lesion area is in the bilateral frontal and temporal lobes with a mixed signal of uneven high and low intensity with patchy high signal areas. Edema is pronounced, chiefly observed in the bilateral lateral frontal lobes, with significant swelling of surrounding tissues, extensive and extending into the temporal lobes. Necrosis is located at the center of the bilateral lateral frontal lobes, characterized by high signal areas interspersed with low signals, primarily in the aforementioned areas. Ventricular compression is notably present as the right ventricle is compressed and deformed, whereas the left ventricle maintains a normal shape.
